problem_text: Let G be a group, F a free group with free generators x1, . . . , xn, and R the free product of G and F. An equation (in the unknowns x1, . . . , xn) over G is an expression of the form v(x1, . . . xn) = 1, where on the left is an element of R not conjugate in R to any element of G. We call G algebraically closed if every equation over G has a solution in G. Do there exist algebraically closed groups? L. A. Bokut’
answer: Yes, such groups do exist (S. D. Brodski˘ı, Dep. no. 2214-80, VINITI, Moscow, 1980 (Russian)).
